g.text: episode, or the whole building average E-index. It is a tool to evaluate occupant exposure
that can be compared across buildings during extreme air pollution events. This can also
be done on a space-by-space basis within the same building.
(ii). Comparison of indoor and outdoor PM
indoor environment mainly by penetration (uncontrolled via building cracks and doors)
or ingress (controlled via mechanical ventilation systemor windows). Fromthe building
operation perspective, quantification of pathways and the quantity of outdoor particles
that enter the indoor environment is one of the most important aspects of building resil-
ience to extreme air pollution events. Considering negligible indoor PM
penetration using indoor to outdoor particle (
is appropriate when the indoor pollution
sources can be neglected, as we determined is the case for this event. We can calculate I/
Oratio at different temporal (i.e., cumulative episode or hourly) and spatial (i.e., whole
building or by room) scales, which informs different scenarios of interest. The differences
between I/Oratios among nearby buildings is typically attributed to differences in indoor
particle sources, geometry of building cracks, wind direction and intensity, ventilation
strategy and rate, and air filtration
. We supplemented the I/Oratio analysis with
information on infiltration rates calculated using CO
was calculated for each indoor sensor location using hourly mean
We defined instantaneous as hourly in this study, but the calculation could be done at smaller
time steps if necessary for a building or space. We used raw measurements fromall sensors so
data was comparable between sensor manufacturer. To calculate the whole building
used the median hourly mean PM
concentration; we used the median value instead of the mean
because it is robust to outlier instances, such as a window being left open which occurred in
is a tool that enables quick-response comparison between
buildings and between spaces within a building on a short time scale.
was calculated for each building to represent the overall whole build-
ing I/Oratio over a given period of time post-event, which was the Chico Camp fire period for
this study. It is the median value of all the mean hourly I/Oratios at each sensor location in a
building during an event. While the
mental conditions and driving forces (e.g. air temperatures and outdoor wind speeds), the
provides an overall value to compare buildings’ abilities to prevent infil-
tration and penetration of outdoor pollutants during extreme pollution events. The
can also be calculated at each sensor location to compare between spaces within a
It may not always be feasible to measure indoor and outdoor
for every building due to sensor availability and cost. A survey is an economical and
IoT sensing tool for determining building resilience
